Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Practical techniques for robotic manipulation of string and wire

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal presents a plan to attack the problem of manipulating flexible materials like string and wire using minimal sensing and actuation. Flexible materials are ubiquitous in manufacturung and surgery, and human examples demonstrate that complex manipulation of flexible materials is possible, from knot-tying to folding laundry or even origami. Robots are currently far less capable in these domains, leaving many boring, repetitive factory tasks inaccessible to robotic automation. Current simulation models of flexible objects are too computationally complex for standard approaches to manipulation planning to be effective. Furthermore, although the simulated dynamic behavior of a piece of string using existing models might be visually believable, the behavior is unlikely to match any particular piece of string in the real world and, therefore, is of limited use.

Knot tying has many applications ranging from manufacturing to surgery to agriculture and service robots. Manipulation of deformable objects is fundamental to many manufacturing and household applications. The proposed work has application to factory operations and seems to apply to potential future needs in manipulation of linear, flexible 1-D structures such as carbon nanotubes and proteins.

Broader Impacts: The development of reliable, inexpensive techniques for manipulation of flexible materials goes beyond the obvious potential impact on factory automation. Minimalism is particularly appropriate for problems involving manipulation at new scales. Fixtures for tying knots might be built at the microscale, allowing parallel manipulation of many very tiny threads or rods. Although we emphasize that the focus of the current work is on theoretical foundations and manipulation at the macro-scale, one can imagine using cleverly-designed geometries to manipulate carbon nano-tubes or proteins - things not possible with standard serial arm designs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to study techniques for the robotic manipulation of string and wire, with a particular focus on developing both robotic hardware and software tools to allow automatic knot tying.


On the technical side, major project outcomes include 1) the invention of simple devices that loosely arrange knots of a particular type, such as the overhand, cloverleaf, or square knot 2) devices that tighten knots precisely, so that, for example, the bows on a shoelace knot are of equal length, and 3) the integration of arrangement and tightening devices into a single machine for knot tying. These machines permit automatic, fast, precise tightening of knots much more complicated than those previously tied in the field of robotics research, and the machines are designed essentially automatically for new knot types using software written for the purpose. The simplicity of the devices allows them to be built rapidly and inexpensively.

Project outcomes also include a better theoretical understanding of knot-tying and string manipulation problems. This includes, for example, formal proofs that any knot, no matter how complicated, can be arranged using a simple device that can be taken apart simply, as long as the string can be threaded through a tube of the needed length. Other proofs study the fundamental difficulty of knot tying, and show how many fingers are required to tie knots of a particular complexity.

The broader impact of this project was primarily educational, training the next generation of scientists and leaders. The project was the main source of support for one graduate student, now a faculty member in his own right. The work was presented at the 2014 USA Science and Engineering Festival (325, 000 attendees), with the goal of introducing younger students to robotics and computer science. The work was presented in the free Dartmouth summer robotics camp for middle-school and high-school students, in the introductory computer science course at Dartmouth, and in the investigator's upper-level artificial intelligence and robotics courses.
